Comments from Committee Members
All of the answers to my letter of inquiry were enthusiastic about the project.
A good many of you had specific suggestions to make about the kits or the develop¬
ment plans® Many comments seemed to relate to the problem of spelling out the
direction or orientation for the kits® Elaine Afton suggested that the kits be
designed for specific group utilization® She felt that there would need to be
kits oriented towards a school board audience® Other kits could be oriented toward
superintendents, principals and curriculum directors. A third set of kits could
be aimed primarily for the teacher who will be presenting televised lessons and a
fourth set of kits designed for teachers using television in the classroom®
Benarr Cooper pushed this idea a little further by saying he felt we had to deter¬
mine what the immediate aim of each one of these kits should be. His concern was
also for the audience with which these kits should be used® He asked, "If we
release this or that particular leit, what can we reasonably expect will be the
result of its release, how will it be used, what will happen when it is used?"
His suggestions organized the kits into two areas for two different groups of
teachers: 1) Teachers in schools where educational broadcasts have not been
tried and are not being used, and 2) Kits for schools where such broadcasts are
being used. This latter group would be broken down into two broad categories:
A) Schools where there is carefully planned use of broadcasts for direct instruc¬
tion and enrichment purposes, and B) Schools where the majority of teachers are
now using such broadcasts as a break in the deadly routine of "mass,'and "messy15
teaching and preparation.
Bernie felt we should make a choice between the two groups in order to tackle the
problem with our limited facilities. He suggested that we concentrate on producing
materials for teachers in group 1 or in areas where educational broadcasts have not
been tried. He also felt that we might concentrate our first efforts towards devel¬
oping or encouragiig utilization workshops. He would tie these into some kind of
local credit arrangement for the teachers participating. Following the workshops,
the kits would then be thought of as follow-up. The comments above about the AACTE
and DAVI bear a little on this orientation but should not necessarily keep us from
thinking of some work in the utilization workshop field.
Wanda Mitchell commented that the areas of need for these kits would be quite varied,
and felt that kits would have to be prepared on a broad basis to be of practical
value. She suggested that the needs might be ascertained by some kind of a survey
to be made at the Classroom Teachers Division meeting at NBA this summer® Our con¬
tacts with the Department of Classroom Teachers on the DAVI invitational s eminar
committee could be cultivated to get this kind of survey made® I would imagine
also that one of the major activities of the invitational seminar, when it takes
place, will be in the ascertaining of specific needs®
In Lew Rhodes1 answer he provided the information regarding the activities of tha
AACTE and reported there was some interest on the part of Dr. Stoddard in financing
a planning meeting for the utilization project. Perhaps there will be something
further on this in the near future since Lev/ would meet with Dr. Stoddard the first
week in March. Lew also felt that the kits should be more closely aimed towards
specific groups ® He commented that kits should be designed for teacher training
institutions, local or regional workshops, and individual school use. I assume
that while there might be some overlapping with some kits some of them would be
specifically produced for the above purposes. He also interjected a new thought
into the project and that is the possibility of making these kits available for
purchase. In our discussions with Dr. McPherson of the Title VII staff, he sug¬
gested that a small rental charge be made for the use of these kits, the money
accruing from these charges to go into future production projects. I think we will
want to talk this over rather carefully,* it does have the intriguing possibility
of keeping the project going but it might throw the v/rong light on the entire purpose.
